entry.title: ios 7.1 will allow developers to release updates more often and reduce nagware
entry.content:
With iOS 7.1 Apple has changed the App Store to show the overall star rating for apps. Currently ratings are only for the latest update. This is great for developers and users alike.

The current system punishes devs for releasing an update by reseting their star rating to 0. This means they hold off on updates until they have enough features and fixes to make it worth the ‘hit’ of resetting their stars.

With auto update introduced in iOS 7 developers can now push out updates almost transparently to users. With the ratings change we can do that without affecting our status in the App Store, so there’s nothing to lose by having all the latest bug fixes released to customers.

There’s been a lot of talk lately about apps nagging or pestering users to leave reviews, with this change the need to update reviews will be taken away which hopefully will reduce nagware.

All in all this is a small but highly significant change for iOS 7.1.

entry.title: finding a graphic designer for iphone
entry.content:
For some reason we thought that finding a graphic designer would be easy…

We’d just post on elance, get loads of replies from talented, experienced and readily available people and then pick one and get some great screens designed.

what we found

As I mentioned in my last post our experience was a little different and we abandoned elance after a frustrating week.

We then moved onto behance and found we had only a slightly better response. We approached one guy whose work we liked, but on speaking with him he didn’t feel like a good fit. We had lots of applicants but a lot didn’t read the brief or provide what we’d asked for.

I then tried looking around on Google. There’s obviously plenty of people to sift through – far too many really -and I went through the first 5 pages of results and contacted a few who I liked. Some weren’t available, some said our budget wasn’t high enough. The rest just couldn’t show us what we wanted to see.

Next I tried LinkedIn. LinkedIn is less cut out for this than I would have expected. Surprisingly few people had their actual work shown online. I found a couple of promising people based solely on their CVs (working with Google, Adobe, Apple, etc) and in the end I did find one person who was our runner up choice.

Finally we got an applicant we liked on behance and after speaking to him on Skype and having a long email conversation with him we’ve decided to go ahead with him. We’re excited to see how it works out. The phrase “how big could this company get if the founders did the right things?” is always in my head when we’re making decisions like this. I’ll let you know how it goes.

what we learned

My biggest take away from this is that we should have allowed a lot more time. Feeling rushed stressed us out and made making a confident decision a lot harder.

Second, right after we’d settled on someone we learned about ooomf. I’d use this next time as it seems to take care of a lot of the hard work for you. I expect the prices would be very high though. (I’d love to hear experiences from either hirers or freelancers on this site).

Third, I wouldn’t use elance again, not for graphic design anyway. I would spend more time combing through behance and dribble looking for people to approach rather than posting a listing and waiting for reactions.

Finally, although at the time I thought we were clear about our requirements I think with hindsight we could have included more detail up front. More importantly I think we could have been more blunt about ignoring people who didn’t send the minimum spec. I’d also set a test like ‘include this phrase at the top of your bid’ to show that candidates have read all the way through the brief.

In short, we’ve learned a lot over the past few weeks and we know what we’d do differently should we need to hire another designer. But, honestly, I really hope we don’t need to go through that process again any time soon.

entry.title: how to apply for graphic design work
entry.content:
We’re looking for a graphic designer at the moment. When we couldn’t get any suitable recommendations from friends we turned to the freelance boards.

When the job was up and posted we expected to get a few copy and pasted responses. But in fact about 90% of the proposals we received made no effort to address the brief at all. Unbelievably, the majority didn’t include a message of any kind, they just sent a link to a portfolio.

We haven’t received a single one that addressed every point.

The brief was to redesign our app and make it iOS 7 ready. Here’s what we said we wanted:

  • Someone who loves their work and takes great pride in it
  • A portfolio full of great iOS app designs, iOS icon designs and iOS app marketing material (the initial work is for the UI design, but we’ll need the other stuff eventually)
  • Links to live apps in the App Store
  • A great communicator who can help us get the most out of the experience

Straight away, the designers who just fired us a link failed the ‘great communicator’ test. Here’s what I think the rest could have done better.

why do you want this job?

This is key. As someone building a product I’m 100% into it. I want to hear that the applicant wants to be part of this.

If you went for a real life job interview the first question you’d be asked is: “Why do you want to work for this company?”

Applying for freelance work is pretty much like a job interview, right? Only without the pressure of a face to face meeting.

If you can’t think of a reason you want the work then save yourself and the hirer some time and don’t apply for the job.

Think about it from my perspective: This project is my life, why would I hire someone who can’t raise enough enthusiasm to tell me why they want to work on it too?

If you do want the work, put the time into writing something that convinces me of this.

relevant experience

The next thing you’d get asked in a job interview is “why do you think you are suitable for this role?”

If you don’t have the experience required, don’t apply for the job

If you have similar experience, but not quite what is asked for AND you really want the job then go into detail about why you think it’s relevant and put extra emphasis into the ‘why’ part. Sell it to me.

how to showcase your work

If you can demonstrate you want to the work and have the required experience, you’re probably in the top 50% of candidates so far.

But your portfolio has be convincing. This is your ace in the hole, the one opportunity you have to demonstrate the kind of skills and innovation we’re looking for. I was surprised to find that even the few candidates who came across well in other areas didn’t take the time to get this right:

1. don’t send a portfolio

That’s right. I’m getting more than a hundred responses to my job post, I don’t want to have to trawl through your 50Mb PDF file trying to identify the examples that are relevant to me.

I want to see two or three (or even one) highly relevant piece of work

So don’t send your whole portfolio, pick out the most relevant things and send those. Include an explanation about why you think those items are relevant. If you can demonstrate that you understand what the hirer wants, you’ll be able to create a much better connection with them.

2. do send graphics that present your work clearly

This was another surprising one. I’m looking for an iPhone app designer, right? So I want to see iPhone screens. I want to see the detail of the UI you’ve slaved over and crafted. I don’t want to see something rendered in 3D or something so over-designed that it obscures your work.

The screens here look really well designed. At least the first one does… if I tilt my head a bit. The others look like they might be well designed, but it’s hard to be sure because they’re hidden.

Don’t use nice effects at the expense of making it easy to view your work

3. do send real world examples

Even better than properly presented graphics is a live product. In fact, if you have links to a product in the App Store, you don’t even need to send graphics.

Only 2% of applications sent us links to apps in the store

That’s even though we specified that we wanted to see links in the brief. For the rest, we had to dig around ourselves to check if their designs had indeed made it into the store. It’s a lame excuse to say you can’t provide a link because you were ‘just’ the designer – if we could find them (eventually), then so could you.

If you can send promo codes too it shows a level of proof and confidence that will be impossible to ignore

Don’t have promo codes for your previous work? Ask the developer/hirer for a few, even offer to buy them of them. Trust me, sending promo codes will make you look great.

Under 30 SEO wrote a great piece. There’s no excuse people!

entry.title: how do we get better?
entry.content:
We sat down in a trendy art cafe in Chiang Mai. We wanted to work out what to do next with the app. We had a few unfinished features and a few unanswered questions. In short we needed some direction.

We started writing on cards all the things we wanted to do in all areas of the app, features, marketing, everything. As we got them down it became clear that there was a kind of hierarchy of goals. And we sorted the cards into the appropriate category.

Here’s the hierarchy that we saw:

Although they all feed up, it’s possible to address things at the higher levels specifically. For example, getting more reviews could come from thinking more carefully about how and when we ask for reviews. And more downloads could come from improved screenshots or app store wording.

This was kind of a revelation for me. As a developer it’s so easy to get tied into the ground level view where you want to add features. The reviews thing in particular, we have a bit of code that prompts the user after a number of times of using the app and we thought about the wording and how many uses was ok before asking. But we didn’t think much beyond that. Might things like time of day make a difference? The more we thought about it the more we thought it would.

We also realised there was a lot more analytics we could be collecting to help us understand our customers better and make more informed decisions about which features to include.

So we’ve decided to park the new features and focus purely on the science of getting more review and more downloads for a little bit. As well as collecting more data to help us decide how to approach increasing engagement.

Here’s the plan:

  • Refine which screens on the app will ask a user for a review. Never ask just when the app opens
  • Add reporting to know how many times we ask for a review and how many times people say yes, no and later
  • A/B test the time of day to ask for a review. I have a theory that for our app asking in the afternoon will give better results than in the morning, but I want to test that
  • Add events for data collection and add goals in analytics
  • Collect data about which model our users are using. For whatever reason analytics doesn’t gather this by default. This is particularly important as iOS 7 approaches as some devices will not be able to upgrade

entry.title: the beginning
entry.content:
It all started with trying to fit into my wedding suit – as all good app development stories do. A healthy intake of beers and burgers had given me a few too many extra inches around the belly and those inches needed to come off. Diets aren’t really my thing but Tim Ferriss’ Four Hour Body appealed to the geek in me because it’s closer to science than most. He’s dug into the chemistry, there’s a definite ‘right and wrong’ way of doing it (the fewer decisions required, the better), and he measures everything – in spreadsheets, no less. If ever there was a man-friendly diet, this is it.

One of 4HB’s commandments is that you consistently measure your arms, hips, waist and legs in order to calculate your Total Body Measurements, and then track this figure along with your body fat percentage. But the spreadsheet just didn’t cut it.

I’d been looking to get into iPhone development for a while so I decided to roll my own body measurements tracking app as a learning project. As it was just for me it didn’t need to be too polished, but being a big fan of Apple products I also wanted to include the native controls and gestures to make it feel as much like a proper iPhone app as possible.

The first version was pretty basic, but way better than a spreadsheet. After using it for a while it occurred to me that other 4HBers might also want an easier way of tracking their measurements. So, without polishing or refining, I put it on the App Store to see what happened. And people downloaded it. Not in their thousands, but enough to make me think there was a market I could tap into to make some money. So there it was: No monetization strategy, no marketing plan, no slick design or well thought out UI. My first app was quick and dirty, but it’s evolved into something I’m really proud of. And it helped me get into that wedding suit.
